results.name: Array read by descending antidiagonals: A(n,k) is the number of oriented colorings of the facets (or vertices) of a regular n-dimensional simplex using up to k colors.
comment: For n=1, the figure is a line segment with two vertices. For n=2, the figure is a triangle with three edges. For n=3, the figure is a tetrahedron with four triangular faces. The Schläfli symbol, {3,...,3}, of the regular n-dimensional simplex consists of n-1 threes. Each of its n+1 facets is a regular (n-1)-dimensional simplex. Two oriented colorings are the same if one is a rotation of the other; chiral pairs are counted as two.
link: Robert A. Russell, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..1275
formula: Linear recurrence for row n: A(n,k) = Sum_{j=1..n+2} -binomial(j-n-3,j) * A(n,k-j).
example: For A(1,2) = 4, the two achiral colorings use just one of the two colors for both vertices; the chiral pair uses two colors. For A(2,2)=4, the triangle may have 0, 1, 2, or 3 edges of one color.
xref: Cf. A325000 (unoriented), A325000(n,k-n) (chiral), A325001 (achiral), A325002 (exactly k colors), A327083 (edges, ridges), A337883 (faces, peaks), A325004 (orthotope facets, orthoplex vertices), A325012 (orthoplex facets, orthotope vertices).
